Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 05:12PM NewToCancer wrote: I just finished the 18th of 33 treatments.  As far as exercise goes, my doctor is allowing me to swim everyday and it has helped to keep my muscles and my spirits strong and my energy level up.  I am a 64 year old couch potatoe.  Yesterday was the first time I felt any irritation under my arm.  I am in the water doing exercises with the water weights and noodle for about an hour each day.  I've started leaving the one strap off my suit, to cut down on any possible irritation.  I asked the pool manager if I could wear a tee shirt in the water, and she agreed.  Hope I can keep swimming until this is all over.  It really makes a difference.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 11:08AM NewToCancer wrote: I have thirteen more rads including the boosts (done 12/5).  I haven't had the problem with the taste in my mouth, but my taste buds are really off.  Foods I normally love just don't taste very good anymore.  I make a dish, taste it and throw it away. I asked whether the taste buds are affected and they said no, but I am not so sure about that.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 11:17AM NewToCancer wrote: I am weighed once a week and the weight has stayed consistent.  They had no problem with me swimming everyday, which has helped with arm movement, strength and has continued to help emotionally.  If I miss a day of swimming, I get down in the dumps and head for bed.  I have a total of 33 rads with only 13 more to go including the boosts.  Today the tech lent me a snorkel mask and tube.  I used it this afternoon and it does help with the arm movements.  I probably looked pretty silly snorkeling in the pool but I really don't care.   They did the markings for the boosts today.  More purple ink and another bathing suit with stains!
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 03:29PM NewToCancer wrote: I forgot to mention that I tried the Aloe Vera Gel and it gave me a rash.  Probably from the alcohol. My doctor suggested that next time I decide to try a new product, I put a little on the inner part of my wrist and not apply freely to the breast.  OK, I've learned my lesson.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2008 11:18AM NewToCancer wrote: I started rads on October 21.  My prescription for Xclair should come in the mail next week (1 tube).  I have to find some other creme to use.  The Xclair is $138 per tube. My insurance covered $38.  The prescription is for 7 tubes, so they must be pretty small.  Does anyone have a creme they would recommend?  I bought Aloe Vera Gel and also a tube of Lanolin Hydrous.  The lanolin is so thick I know it will not be easy to apply to sore skin. The aloe vera has alcohol in it.  I am really hoping someone can head me in the right direction.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 03:26PM NewToCancer wrote: The Xclair doesn't have any alcohol in it.  The cost of $138 was for 3 tubes.  The doctor gave me a coupon for $30 refund and my insurance covered $38, so it isn't as bad as I thought.  The nurse gave me several samples as well.  She recommended the Aquafor, so I will be getting a tube of that as well.  And also Hydrocortisone 1% cream plus 12 moisturizers, maximum strength (no alcohol in it) so I'll be checking it out also.  I guess the Xclair is pretty good stuff, but a little too expensive for me.  I will be very careful with the 3 tubes, knowing I will not be sending in for refills.
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: NewToCancer wrote: I've tried looking up the term sub centimeter with no success. Does it mean a mass smaller than one centimeter? They want me to return for supplemental images of the right breast and possible ultrasound. As soon as I hit the Save I realized that if I split into two words, I would get an answer. It is a mass smaller than one centimeter. Here I go again. It has been ten years since I had cancer in my left breast. The breasts were both reduced and I did radiation. I know things have changed in the last ten years, but if this is cancer, which I suspect, I still don't want the chemo. When I was in ten years ago, they did see a very small mass or whatever you want to call it in the right breast, but it was too small to mark or find. This may be the same one. For some reason I am not as upset as last time. Maybe because I know what to expect and I went through it once and plan on doing it again. Or maybe it is because I am 75 years old, kids are grown and on their own. This website helped me soooooo much through the first time. I am not telling my kids about it this time. I moved to Nashville, TN where my daughter is now living with the grandchildren. So it will be a new hospital and a new doctor in a location of which I am not familiar. I will think of it as an adventure. GDN Dx 8/11/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Subcentimeter mass in the interior central right breast. NewToCancer MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: NewToCancer wrote: I am wondering if anyone else has had a change in their taste buds.  I can't find anything that is worth eating.  Foods I have always loved, recipes that have always been delicious now either are tasteless or just plain and simply taste like crap!   I wonder if that is the reason my onco said "Everyone looses weight during radiation".  GDN Dx 8/11/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taste Buds NewToCancer Westie
